awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Increasing Student Engagement through Adaptive Instructional Video Delivery
awd_abstract_narration:
This SBIR Phase II project addresses low student engagement through a dynamic video delivery environment, with a novel, real-time algorithm that adjusts the instructional pathway to each student's readiness level. Researchers consider disengaged pupils as the largest challenge facing teachers, as between 25% and 66% of students are considered to be disengaged (Taylor and Parsons 2011). As a solution, adapting instruction to each student's learning background has long been touted as one of the most effective methods to drive student engagement (Como & Snow 1986). After all, when instruction is individualized to the background of the student, engagement and outcomes increase dramatically (Corbett 2001). By calibrating video segments (using factors such as syntactic and lexical complexity) to the student's readiness, this project will guarantee appropriately challenging instruction to most effectively sustain engagement. This will be extremely useful for improving engagement and outcomes for all STEM students and, most pointedly, will impact English Language Learners (ELL) who often fall behind in STEM classes because instruction is beyond their readiness and in-class support is insufficient. Considering that, according to the National Education Association, ELL population is the fastest-growing population of public school students in the U.S., this project has a huge potential to drive a STEM proficient workforce.

This project will result in a prototype instructional solution that uses algorithms to match video segment complexity with student readiness. This novel, pedagogically-sound approach sets itself apart from other adaptive solutions with its K12 STEM focus and proprietary frameworks. With its roots in the leading interactive video solution, this project is made possible through access to a large database of tagged and curated videos (400,000+) and questions (2.5 million+) and provides an unprecedented opportunity to develop adaptive instructional pathways for a diverse learning spectrum. The objective of this research is to prove this project can feasibly increase engagement, or psychological investment in learning, of science students and spark the next generation of adaptive instruction. For Phase I, the project team will deploy in classrooms a fully functioning prototype of a product built around a 10 lesson Physical Science unit. The team will employ stimulated recall interviewing technique, speak aloud interview protocols, and quantitative usage logs to assess the feasibility of highly-adaptive video instruction to increase student engagement.

por.por_cntn:
AdaptivePosit by PlayPosit (https://www.playposit.com) engages learners through a dynamic interactive video delivery environment with a novel back-end algorithm that adjusts the video pathway to each learner’s proficiency. Embedded formative assessment quizzes within the interactive video module serve to assess understanding, as a core underlying input into the proprietary algorithm, and redirect the learner to an appropriately complex video segment. By relying upon the mediums of video instructional training and embedded formative assessments, AdaptivePosit takes a multi-modal learning approach and covers the diverse learning styles of a classroom.

 

Intellectual Merit

The project team piloted innovative algorithms and formulas to assess student proficiency and match appropriately complex video segments to the student’s background. The three components of research-founded differentiation are:

  1. A formula to assess and measure student complexity level,
  2. A formula to assess and curate video segment complexity,
  3. And lastly, a continuously honed algorithm to appropriately and accurately match students with video segments.

Core to all three components are the following factors that feed into the formulas and algorithms: Depth of Knowledge of questions and examples provided, the syntactic complexity of videos, and the lexical complexity of the videos.

The project’s technical objective was to examine how integrating an adaptive video approach into classroom instruction relates to learner engagement.

 

Broader Impacts

Considering low levels of engagement leads to students falling behind, losing interest, and potentially dropping out, this is a pressing problem that requires attention (Alexander,

Entwisle, and Horsey 1997). Many researchers consider disengaged pupils as the largest challenges facing teachers, as between 25% and 66% of students are considered to be disengaged (Taylor and Parsons 2011). When students have high motivation and engagement in learning, they are consistently linked to increased levels of proficiency (Blank, 1997; Dev, 1997; Kushman, 2000).

Research evidence suggests students are more deeply engaged when all components of their learning pathway accommodate their learning styles and proficiency; when this occurs, it is termed an adaptive pathway (Jung and Park 2008).

Adapting instruction to each student’s learning background has long been touted as one of the most effective methods to drive student engagement and outcomes. When instruction is individualized to the background of the student, outcomes increase dramatically. For instance, when educators have the time and resources to cater their instruction to each student, students receive as much as two standard deviations higher results than students in conventional instruction (Corbett 2001).

With the personalized and dynamic environment of AdaptivePosit, the project team intends to achieve the same improvement in student results.

After deploying AdaptivePosit, mixed methods and psychometric evaluations were employed to assess levels of engagement and learning outcomes achieved. Phase I feasibility results indicated that video tracks were correctly adapting for learners, providing a moderate challenge, and preparing students for the embedded questions ahead. Moreover, quantitative and qualitative indicators suggested that learners found the adaptive module engaging and a preferred method over traditional instructional practices.

The encouraging results from Phase I provide evidence for the development of a more robust adaptive algorithm pathway in Phase II. By combinin historical student data points (scores, reactions to videos, and general viewing behavior), teacher categorizations of readiness, and performance on question sets, Phase II AdaptivePosit will be able to paint an accurate learner profile and deliver appropriately complex video segments at all points of the video module.
